column2: Chapter Ten
column3: Chapter Ten

column2: Shaggy Man to the Rescue
column3: Shaggy Man to the Rescue

column2: They had not gone very far before Bungle, who had run on ahead, came bounding back to say that the road of yellow bricks was just before them.
column3: They had not gone very far before Bungle, who had run on ahead, came bounding back to say that the road of yellow bricks was just before them.

column2: At once they hurried forward to see what this famous road looked like.
column3: At once they hurried forward to see what this famous road looked like.

column2: It was a broad road, but not straight, for it wandered over hill and dale and picked out the easiest places to go.
column3: It was a broad road, but not straight, for it wandered over hill and dale and picked out the easiest places to go.

column2: All its length and breadth was paved with smooth bricks of a bright yellow color, so it was smooth and level except in a few places where the bricks had crumbled or been removed, leaving holes that might cause the unwary to stumble.
column3: All its length and breadth was paved with smooth bricks of a bright yellow color, so it was smooth and level except in a few places where the bricks had crumbled or been removed, leaving holes that might cause the unwary to stumble.

column2: I wonder, said Ojo, looking up and down the road, "which way to go."
column3: I wonder, said Ojo, looking up and down the road, "which way to go."

column2: The Emerald City, he replied.
column3: The Emerald City, he replied.

column2: Have you ever been to the Emerald City? asked Scraps.
column3: Have you ever been to the Emerald City? asked Scraps.

column2: Are you afraid of men? inquired the Patchwork Girl.
column3: Are you afraid of men? inquired the Patchwork Girl.

column2: Me?	Me?
With my heart-rending growl--my horrible, shudderful growl?
column3: With my heart rending growl-my horrible, shudderful growl?

column2: I am not afraid of anything," declared the Woozy.
column3: I am not afraid of anything," declared the Woozy.

column2: I wish I could say the same, sighed Ojo.
column3: I wish I could say the same, sighed Ojo.

column2: If anything should fade the colors of my lovely patches it would break my heart, said the Patchwork Girl.
column3: If anything should fade the colors of my lovely patches it would break my heart, said the Patchwork Girl.

column2: I'm not sure you have a heart, Ojo reminded her.
column3: I'm not sure you have a heart, Ojo reminded her.

column2: Then it would break my cotton, persisted Scraps.
column3: Then it would break my cotton, persisted Scraps.

column2: Do you think they are all fast colors, Ojo? she asked anxiously.
column3: Do you think they are all fast colors, Ojo? she asked anxiously.

column2: They were certainly pretty to look upon and the travelers hurried forward to observe them more closely.
column3: They were certainly pretty to look upon and the travelers hurried forward to observe them more closely.

column2: But the most curious thing about the swaying leaves was their color.
column3: But the most curious thing about the swaying leaves was their color.

column2: Suddenly a leaf bent lower than usual and touched the Patchwork Girl. Swiftly it enveloped her in its embrace, covering her completely in its thick folds, and then it swayed back upon its stem.
column3: Suddenly a leaf bent lower than usual and touched the Patchwork Girl. Swiftly it enveloped her in its embrace, covering her completely in its thick folds, and then it swayed back upon its stem.

column2: But, before he could think what he ought to do to save her, another leaf bent down and captured the Glass Cat, rolling around the little creature until she was completely hidden, and then straightening up again upon its stem.
column3: But, before he could think what he ought to do to save her, another leaf bent down and captured the Glass Cat, rolling around the little creature until she was completely hidden, and then straightening up again upon its stem.

column2: Look out, cried the Woozy.
column3: Look out, cried the Woozy.

column2: But the last leaf of the row of plants seized the beast even as he ran and instantly he disappeared from sight.
column3: But the last leaf of the row of plants seized the beast even as he ran and instantly he disappeared from sight.

column2: Half a dozen of the great leaves were bending toward him from different directions and as he stood hesitating one of them clutched him in its embrace.
column3: Half a dozen of the great leaves were bending toward him from different directions and as he stood hesitating one of them clutched him in its embrace.

column2: In a flash he was in the dark. Then he felt himself gently lifted until he was swaying in the air, with the folds of the leaf hugging him on all sides.
column3: In a flash he was in the dark. Then he felt himself gently lifted until he was swaying in the air, with the folds of the leaf hugging him on all sides.

column2: Then Ojo quieted himself and tried to think.
column3: Then Ojo quieted himself and tried to think.

column2: Despair fell upon him when he remembered that all his little party had been captured, even as he was, and there was none to save them.
column3: Despair fell upon him when he remembered that all his little party had been captured, even as he was, and there was none to save them.

column2: I might have expected it, he sobbed, miserably.
column3: I might have expected it, he sobbed, miserably.

column2: I'm Ojo the Unlucky, and something dreadful was sure to happen to me.
column3: I'm Ojo the Unlucky, and something dreadful was sure to happen to me.

column2: He pushed against the leaf that held him and found it to be soft, but thick and firm.
column3: He pushed against the leaf that held him and found it to be soft, but thick and firm.

column2: It was like a great bandage all around him and he found it difficult to move his body or limbs in order to change their position.
column3: It was like a great bandage all around him and he found it difficult to move his body or limbs in order to change their position.

column2: The minutes passed and became hours.
column3: The minutes passed and became hours.

column2: Ojo wondered how long one could live in such a condition and if the leaf would gradually sap his strength and even his life, in order to feed itself.
column3: Ojo wondered how long one could live in such a condition and if the leaf would gradually sap his strength and even his life, in order to feed itself.

column2: His greatest fear at this time was that he would always remain imprisoned in the beautiful leaf and never see the light of day again.
column3: His greatest fear at this time was that he would always remain imprisoned in the beautiful leaf and never see the light of day again.

column2: The sounds were low and sweet and, although they reached Ojo's ears very faintly, they were clear and harmonious.
column3: The sounds were low and sweet and, although they reached Ojo's ears very faintly, they were clear and harmonious.

column2: Could the leaf whistle, Ojo wondered?
column3: Could the leaf whistle, Ojo wondered?

column2: Suddenly the whole leaf toppled and fell, carrying the boy with it, and while he sprawled at full length the folds slowly relaxed and set him free.
column3: Suddenly the whole leaf toppled and fell, carrying the boy with it, and while he sprawled at full length the folds slowly relaxed and set him free.

column2: He scrambled quickly to his feet and found that a strange man was standing before him--a man so curious in appearance that the boy stared with round eyes.
column3: He scrambled quickly to his feet and found that a strange man was standing before him-a man so curious in appearance that the boy stared with round eyes.

column2: He was a big man, with shaggy whiskers, shaggy eyebrows, shaggy hair--but kindly blue eyes that were gentle as those of a cow.
column3: He was a big man, with shaggy whiskers, shaggy eyebrows, shaggy hair-but kindly blue eyes that were gentle as those of a cow.

column2: Rich but shaggy laces were at his throat; a coat with shaggy edges was decorated with diamond buttons; the velvet breeches had jeweled buckles at the knees and shags all around the bottoms.
column3: Rich but shaggy laces were at his throat; a coat with shaggy edges was decorated with diamond buttons; the velvet breeches had jeweled buckles at the knees and shags all around the bottoms.

column2: On his breast hung a medallion bearing a picture of Princess Dorothy of Oz, and in his hand, as he stood looking at Ojo, was a sharp knife shaped like a dagger.
column3: On his breast hung a medallion bearing a picture of Princess Dorothy of Oz, and in his hand, as he stood looking at Ojo, was a sharp knife shaped like a dagger.

column2: Yes; I can see that, said the boy, nodding.
column3: Yes; I can see that, said the boy, nodding.

column2: None other, you may be sure.	None other, you may be sure.
But take care, or I shall have to rescue you again."
column3: But take care, or I shall have to rescue you again."

column2: Singing or whistling--it doesn't matter which--makes 'em behave, and nothing else will.	Singing or whistling-it doesn't matter which-makes 'em behave, and nothing else will.
I always whistle as I go by 'em and so they always let me alone.
column3: I always whistle as I go by 'em and so they always let me alone.

column2: To-day as I went by, whistling, I saw a leaf curled and knew there must be something inside it.
column3: To day as I went by, whistling, I saw a leaf curled and knew there must be something inside it.

column2: I cut down the leaf with my knife and--out you popped.
column3: I cut down the leaf with my knife and-out you popped.

column2: Lucky I passed by, wasn't it?"
column3: Lucky I passed by, wasn't it?"

column2: You were very kind, said Ojo, "and I thank you.
column3: You were very kind, said Ojo, "and I thank you.

column2: Will you please rescue my companions, also?"
column3: Will you please rescue my companions, also?"

column2: What companions? asked the Shaggy Man.
column3: What companions? asked the Shaggy Man.

column2: The leaves grabbed them all, said the boy.
column3: The leaves grabbed them all, said the boy.

column2: There's a Patchwork Girl and--
column3: There's a Patchwork Girl and-

column2: She's alive and her name is Scraps.
column3: She's alive and her name is Scraps.

column2: And there's a Glass Cat--"
column3: And there's a Glass Cat-"

column2: Glass? asked the Shaggy Man.
column3: Glass? asked the Shaggy Man.

column2: All glass.
column3: All glass.

column2: What's a Woozy? inquired the Shaggy Man.
column3: What's a Woozy? inquired the Shaggy Man.

column2: Why, I--I--can't describe it, answered the boy, greatly perplexed. "But it's a queer animal with three hairs on the tip of its tail that won't come out and--"
column3: Why, I-I-can't describe it, answered the boy, greatly perplexed. "But it's a queer animal with three hairs on the tip of its tail that won't come out and-"

column2: What won't come out? asked the Shaggy Man; "the tail?"
column3: What won't come out? asked the Shaggy Man; "the tail?"

column2: The hairs won't come out.	The hairs won't come out.
Of course, said the Shaggy Man, nodding his shaggy head.
column3: Of course, said the Shaggy Man, nodding his shaggy head.

column2: And then he walked back among the plants, still whistling, and found the three leaves which were curled around Ojo's traveling companions.
column3: And then he walked back among the plants, still whistling, and found the three leaves which were curled around Ojo's traveling companions.

column2: The first leaf he cut down released Scraps, and on seeing her the Shaggy Man threw back his shaggy head, opened wide his mouth and laughed so shaggily and yet so merrily that Scraps liked him at once.
column3: The first leaf he cut down released Scraps, and on seeing her the Shaggy Man threw back his shaggy head, opened wide his mouth and laughed so shaggily and yet so merrily that Scraps liked him at once.

column2: My dear, you're a wonder.	My dear, you're a wonder.
I must introduce you to my friend the Scarecrow."
column3: I must introduce you to my friend the Scarecrow."

column2: When he cut down the second leaf he rescued the Glass Cat, and Bungle was so frightened that she scampered away like a streak and soon had joined Ojo, when she sat beside him panting and trembling.
column3: When he cut down the second leaf he rescued the Glass Cat, and Bungle was so frightened that she scampered away like a streak and soon had joined Ojo, when she sat beside him panting and trembling.

column2: The last plant of all the row had captured the Woozy, and a big bunch in the center of the curled leaf showed plainly where he was.
column3: The last plant of all the row had captured the Woozy, and a big bunch in the center of the curled leaf showed plainly where he was.
